title: 112_s162
content:
The "Cut Federal Spending Act of 2011" reduces funding for the legislative branch by $1,283,000,000 and defunds the Government Printing Office. The judicial branch's budget for fiscal year 2011 is reduced by $2,434,000,000 on a pro rata basis. SEC. 4. AGRICULTURE. Amounts available to the Department of Agriculture for fiscal year 2011 are reduced by $42,542,000,000. Specific reductions include defunding agencies like the Agriculture Research Service and reducing funds for the Forest Service by $1,178,000,000. SEC. 5. COMMERCE. SEC. 5. COMMERCE. Amounts available to the Department of Commerce for fiscal year 2011 are reduced by a total of $5,322,000,000, with a specific reduction of $857,000,000 for the National Oceanic And Atmospheric Administration. In fiscal year 2011, reductions are made in various areas:
- Military personnel: $14 billion
- Procurement: $13.3 billion
- Operations and maintenance: $22.43 billion
- Research and development: $8 billion
- War funding: $16 billion
Transfers include moving all Department of Energy accounts to the Department of Defense, capped at $17.12 billion. Transfer United States Coast Guard accounts from Department of Homeland Security to Department of Defense, capped at $17,120,000,000. The Department of Education programs are defunded except for the Pell grant program, capped at $16,256,000,000. Department of Energy funding for 2011 is reduced by $27,270,000,000, with remaining funds transferred to the Department of Defense. The Department of Health and Human Services for fiscal year 2011 faces reductions totaling $26,510,000,000, with specific cuts to FDA, Health Resources and Services Administration, Indian Health Service, and the Center for Disease Control and Prevention. For fiscal year 2011, the Department of Health and Human Services faces significant reductions totaling $26,510,000,000. Specific cuts include $1,165,000,000 for the Center for Disease Control and Prevention, $5,825,000,000 for the National Institute of Health, and $626,000,000 for the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Service Administration. SEC. 10. HOMELAND SECURITY. Amounts for Homeland Security in fiscal year 2011 are reduced by $23,765,000,000. This includes transferring funds from the Coast Guard to the Department of Defense and reducing Transportation Security Administration funds by $901,000,000. SEC. 11. HOUSING AND URBAN DEVELOPMENT. Defunding all accounts and programs of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, except for Veteran housing programs which are transferred to the Department of Veterans' Affairs. Amounts available to the Department of Interior for fiscal year 2011 are reduced by $10,934,000,000, with specific reductions to Land and Mineral Management, Bureau of Reclamation, United States Geological Survey, and the national Park Service. Repeal of all Bureau of Indian Affairs accounts and programs, defunding them with an amount of $849,000,000 upon enactment of the Act. SEC. 13. JUSTICE. Amounts for Department of Justice in fiscal year 2011 reduced by $9,057,000,000. All Office of Justice Programs defunded upon enactment.

SEC. 14. LABOR. Department of Labor funds for 2011 reduced by $2,803,000,000. Exemptions include Occupational Safety and Health Administration, Mine Safety and Health Administration, and Employment and Training Administration.

SEC. 15. STATE. SEC. 15. STATE. Department of State funding for fiscal year 2011 reduced by $20,321,000,000 on a pro rata basis. Specific agencies defunded include International Organizations and Conferences, and International Commissions.

SEC. 16. TRANSPORTATION. Department of Transportation funding for fiscal year 2011 reduced by $42,810,000,000 on a pro rata basis. All Amtrak Federal subsidies terminated upon enactment.

SEC. 17. VETERANS' AFFAIRS. Department of Veterans' Affairs exempt from funding cuts in fiscal year 2011. In fiscal year 2011, the Department of Veterans' Affairs is exempt from funding cuts. The Corps of Engineers, Environmental Protection Agency, and General Services Administration face reduced funding, while NASA is not mentioned. In fiscal year 2011, funding cuts are implemented for NASA, the National Science Foundation, and the Office of Personnel Management. The Social Security Administration is exempt from cuts, while independent agencies face a repeal. SEC. 25. REPEAL OF INDEPENDENT AGENCIES. The Affordable Housing Program, Commission on Fine Arts, Consumer Product Safety Commission, Corporation for Public Broadcasting, National Endowment for the Arts, National Endowment for the Humanities, and State Justice Institute are defunded. SEC. 26. FEDERAL COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION. Funding for the Federal Communications Commission in fiscal year 2011 is reduced by $2,150,000,000. SEC. 27. MISCELLANEOUS BUDGET SAVINGS. In fiscal year 2011, various budget savings measures will be implemented or repealed, including collecting delinquent taxes from Federal Employees, freezing Federal Government employee pay, reducing Federal Government travel, repealing Davis-Bacon, prohibiting union labor project agreements, repealing the Troubled Assets Relief Program, selling unused Federal assets, and reducing the Federal vehicle budget. Total savings amount to $44,081,000,000.
